keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up' at the airport.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest, but an AR-15 assault rifle was found in his vehicle parked outside.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle previously was convicted of marijuana possession over 20 years ago and is considered a convicted felon.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, highlighting the severity and national implications of the threat.
The incident occurred at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the world’s busiest airport, making it a globally significant location for such events.
The airport's crowded check-in areas and high volume of passengers underscore the potential for widespread panic and harm had the threat been realized.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens emphasized that the combination of a semi-automatic weapon and mental challenges made the situation potentially deadly.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised law enforcement for preventing a tragedy.
Cartersville police were first alerted by Cagle’s family, who reported he was armed and on his way to the airport, and they coordinated with Atlanta Police Department.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Though not armed at the time of arrest, an AR-15 assault rifle was discovered in his vehicle. Cagle, a convicted felon with a prior marijuana offense, faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assault, and unlawful firearm possession. Authorities, including Atlanta and Cartersville police and the FBI, responded swiftly after receiving early warnings. The incident occurred at a time when the airport—currently the world’s busiest—was crowded, particularly near check-in areas, raising concerns about public safety. Officials, including Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, emphasized the seriousness of the situation, citing the dangerous combination of a firearm and mental health issues. The case highlights the importance of early intervention, inter-agency coordination, and the critical role of community vigilance in preventing tragedies at high-traffic public venues.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to 'Shoot It Up'
